canonical_explanation.text: Patterns are everywhere in the real world — in nature (petals, honeycomb, snowflakes), in Indian art and culture (rangoli, kolam, mehndi, jali work, block printing), and in everyday life (tiles, wallpaper, fabric). Recognising, describing, and creating patterns helps us understand structure and predict what comes next.
rules: Nature has many patterns: flower petals, honeycomb hexagons, spirals in shells
Indian art uses repeating patterns: rangoli, kolam, mehndi designs, tile work
Patterns in architecture: jali screens, floor tiles, window grills
A pattern rule tells you how the pattern repeats or grows
You can create your own patterns by choosing a shape/colour rule and applying it
Describing a pattern means stating what repeats and how

questions.question_text: Honeycomb cells are shaped like:
questions.explanation_correct: Honeycomb cells are hexagonal (6-sided) in shape. Bees build them this way because hexagons fit together without gaps.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Honeycomb = hexagonal pattern. Hexagons tessellate perfectly.

questions.question_text: A sunflower often shows a ___ pattern in its seeds.
questions.explanation_correct: Sunflower seeds are arranged in spiral patterns. These spirals follow mathematical rules found in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sunflower seeds grow in spiral patterns, a common pattern in nature.

questions.question_text: A snowflake has a symmetrical pattern.
questions.explanation_correct: Snowflakes have 6-fold symmetry — they look the same when rotated by 60°. Each arm mirrors the others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Snowflakes are symmetrical with 6 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: Rangoli designs are a tradition of:
questions.explanation_correct: Rangoli is a traditional Indian art form where patterns are drawn on the floor using coloured powders, especially during festivals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rangoli is an Indian art tradition, commonly made during Diwali and other festivals.

questions.question_text: Kolam designs from South India are typically drawn using:
questions.explanation_correct: Kolam is drawn by placing dots in a grid pattern and connecting them with curved or looped lines to create symmetrical designs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kolam uses a dot grid pattern with curved/looped lines connecting the dots.

questions.question_text: To describe a pattern, you should explain:

options.text: What repeats and how it changes

questions.explanation_correct: Describing a pattern means telling what the repeating unit is and how it repeats (or how the pattern grows/changes).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A good pattern description explains: what repeats, in what order, and how it changes.

questions.question_text: The spots on a butterfly's wings usually show:
questions.explanation_correct: A butterfly's wings are symmetrical — the pattern on the left wing mirrors the right wing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Butterfly wings display bilateral symmetry: left mirrors right.

questions.question_text: Mehndi (henna) designs on hands use repeating patterns.
questions.explanation_correct: Mehndi designs use repeating motifs like paisleys, flowers, leaves, and lines arranged in patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mehndi designs are full of repeating patterns — flowers, leaves, curves, and paisleys.

questions.question_text: Which natural pattern involves hexagons?
questions.explanation_correct: Honeycombs are made of hexagonal cells. This is one of the most common hexagonal patterns in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Honeycomb cells are hexagons — a perfect natural example of hexagonal patterns.

questions.question_text: Petals on many flowers come in groups that follow a pattern. A lily commonly has:
questions.explanation_correct: Lilies typically have 6 petals (or more precisely, 3 petals and 3 sepals that look like petals). Many flowers have petal counts that follow patterns in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lilies commonly have 6 petal-like parts (3 petals + 3 sepals).

questions.question_text: In Indian architecture, a jali screen is a pattern of:
questions.explanation_correct: Jali is a perforated screen with carved geometric or floral patterns. It allows light and air through while maintaining privacy. Famous examples include those at Hawa Mahal, Jaipur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Jali screens are carved stone or wood with repeating geometric openings — found in Mughal and Rajasthani architecture.

questions.question_text: Block printing in Rajasthan creates patterns by:

options.text: Stamping a carved wooden block repeatedly on fabric

questions.explanation_correct: Block printing uses a carved wooden block dipped in dye and pressed repeatedly onto fabric, creating a repeating pattern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Block printing uses a carved block stamped repeatedly to create a repeating design on fabric.

questions.question_text: Anita creates a pattern for a border: red bead, blue bead, blue bead, red bead, blue bead, blue bead. The core of her pattern is:
questions.explanation_correct: The core that repeats is: red, blue, blue (3 beads), then it starts again with red, blue, blue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Core = red, blue, blue — this group of 3 repeats.

questions.question_text: A tile floor has the pattern: white, white, grey, white, white, grey. The repeating core has ___ tiles.
questions.explanation_correct: Core = white, white, grey — 3 tiles in the repeating unit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The repeating unit is white, white, grey = 3 tiles.

questions.question_text: Tree rings show a pattern related to:

options.text: The tree's age (one ring per year)
The type of fruit it bears

questions.explanation_correct: Each ring in a tree trunk represents one year of growth. Counting rings tells you the tree's age.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tree rings: each ring = one year. Wider rings = good growing years, narrow = tough years.

questions.question_text: The Taj Mahal has symmetrical patterns in its design.
questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal is famous for its symmetry — the left side mirrors the right side. Its inlay work and carvings also use repeating patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Taj Mahal displays remarkable bilateral symmetry and repeating geometric patterns.

questions.question_text: Ravi describes his pattern as: 'Start with a square, then a circle, then a triangle — repeat.' Which shows his pattern?

options.text: Square, circle, triangle, square, circle, triangle

questions.explanation_correct: The description says: square, circle, triangle — repeat. So the pattern is: square, circle, triangle, square, circle, triangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Core = square, circle, triangle. The pattern repeats this core.

questions.question_text: Spider webs display which type of pattern?
questions.explanation_correct: Spider webs (especially orb webs) show radial symmetry — silk threads spread outward from the centre in a regular pattern with spiral threads connecting them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spider webs have radial symmetry: threads radiate from the centre like spokes of a wheel.

questions.question_text: Which of these is NOT an example of a pattern in nature?
questions.explanation_correct: A brick is a man-made object, not a natural pattern. Zebra stripes, ladybird spots, and snail shell spirals are all patterns found in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bricks are man-made. Zebra stripes, ladybird spots, and shell spirals are natural patterns.

questions.question_text: Which Indian art form creates patterns on the floor using rice powder or coloured powder?
questions.explanation_correct: Rangoli (North India) and Kolam (South India) are floor art forms made with rice powder, coloured sand, or flower petals in geometric patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rangoli and Kolam are floor patterns made with powders — a living tradition across India.

questions.question_text: A student creates a number pattern for decoration: 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 2, 1, 1, 2. The core of this pattern has ___ numbers.
questions.explanation_correct: Core = 1, 1, 2 — 3 numbers that repeat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The repeating core is 1, 1, 2 (length 3).

questions.question_text: Leaves arranged around a stem often follow a ___ pattern.
questions.explanation_correct: Many plants arrange their leaves in a spiral pattern around the stem. This helps each leaf get maximum sunlight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaves on many plants grow in a spiral arrangement called phyllotaxis.

questions.question_text: Traditional Indian floor tiles often use:
questions.explanation_correct: Indian floor tiles traditionally use repeating geometric patterns — stars, flowers, interlocking shapes in multiple colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Traditional Indian tiles feature repeating geometric patterns with multiple colours.

questions.question_text: Creating a pattern means arranging things in a regular, predictable way.
questions.explanation_correct: A pattern has a rule and is predictable — you can tell what comes next because the arrangement follows a regular order.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Patterns are regular and predictable — the opposite of random.

questions.question_text: Pineapple skin shows:
questions.explanation_correct: Pineapple skin has a clear pattern of diamond (or hexagonal) shaped sections arranged in spirals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pineapple skin displays diamond-shaped sections in a spiral pattern.

questions.question_text: Warli art from Maharashtra uses which basic shapes for patterns?
questions.explanation_correct: Warli art uses three basic shapes: a triangle, a circle, and a square to create patterns depicting daily life, nature, and celebrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Warli art is based on three shapes: triangle, circle, and square — used to create human figures, animals, and scenes.

questions.question_text: Priya describes her rangoli border as: 'Two red dots, one yellow dot, repeat.' The 15th dot is:
questions.explanation_correct: Core = red, red, yellow (3 dots). 15 ÷ 3 = 5 remainder 0. A remainder of 0 means it's the last in the core = yellow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 15 ÷ 3 = 5 exactly. The 15th dot is the 3rd in the core = yellow.

questions.question_text: The shape of each cell in a honeycomb is a ___
questions.explanation_correct: Honeycomb cells are hexagonal — each cell is a regular hexagon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Honeycomb cells are hexagons (6-sided regular polygons).

questions.question_text: Mughal architecture in India often features:
questions.explanation_correct: Mughal architecture is famous for symmetrical designs featuring floral motifs, geometric patterns, and intricate inlay work (as seen in the Taj Mahal, Red Fort, etc.).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mughal buildings feature symmetrical floral and geometric patterns in stone, inlay, and painting.

questions.question_text: Aman creates a border pattern. He uses 3 green beads, then 2 white beads, and repeats. How many green beads are in the first 20 beads?
questions.explanation_correct: Core = 3 green + 2 white = 5 beads. In 20 beads: 20 ÷ 5 = 4 complete cores. Each core has 3 green. Total green = 4 × 3 = 12.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 20 beads ÷ 5 per core = 4 cores. 4 × 3 green = 12 green beads.

questions.question_text: Which animal has a striped pattern on its body?
questions.explanation_correct: Tigers have distinctive black stripes on their orange fur — a repeating pattern that helps them camouflage in grass and forests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tigers have black stripes on orange fur — one of nature's most recognizable patterns.

questions.question_text: Seashells often have spiral patterns.
questions.explanation_correct: Many seashells (like nautilus, conch) grow in spiral patterns. The spiral is one of the most common patterns in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seashells commonly display spiral patterns as they grow outward.

questions.question_text: The floor art made with rice powder in Tamil Nadu is called ___
questions.explanation_correct: Kolam is the traditional floor art from Tamil Nadu, drawn with rice powder, usually in front of houses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kolam is the Tamil Nadu tradition of drawing patterns on the floor with rice powder.

questions.question_text: Which of these is an example of a pattern in everyday life?
questions.explanation_correct: Floor tiles are arranged in a repeating pattern. Scattered leaves, rock piles, and single clouds do not necessarily show patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Floor tiles follow a regular repeating pattern — an everyday example of patterns.

questions.question_text: A peacock's tail feathers display:

options.text: Repeating eye-like spots in a fan pattern

questions.explanation_correct: A peacock's tail has repeating eye-like spots (ocelli) arranged in a fan-shaped display — a beautiful example of patterns in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peacock tail feathers have repeating 'eye' spots in a symmetrical fan arrangement.

questions.question_text: In a traditional Indian saree border, the pattern usually:

options.text: Repeats the same motif along the entire length

questions.explanation_correct: Saree borders feature a repeating motif (flowers, paisleys, geometric shapes) that runs along the entire border length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saree borders have a repeating design — the same motif appears over and over.

questions.question_text: Neha creates a clap pattern: clap-clap-snap, clap-clap-snap, clap-clap-snap. She performs 30 actions. How many snaps are there?
questions.explanation_correct: Core = clap, clap, snap (3 actions, 1 snap). 30 ÷ 3 = 10 complete cores. Total snaps = 10 × 1 = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 30 actions ÷ 3 per core = 10 cores. Each core has 1 snap. Total = 10 snaps.

questions.question_text: Which of these shows bilateral symmetry in nature?

options.text: A leaf (left half mirrors right half)

questions.explanation_correct: Many leaves show bilateral symmetry — the left half is a mirror image of the right half along the central vein.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaves often have bilateral symmetry: the midrib acts as a line of symmetry.

questions.question_text: The Hawa Mahal in Jaipur is famous for its:
questions.explanation_correct: Hawa Mahal (Palace of Winds) has 953 small windows arranged in a honeycomb-like pattern on its facade — a stunning example of repeating patterns in Indian architecture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hawa Mahal features a facade with 953 small windows in a repeating geometric pattern.

questions.question_text: A kolam design starts with a 3×3 dot grid. How many dots are used?
questions.explanation_correct: A 3×3 grid has 3 rows and 3 columns: 3 × 3 = 9 dots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 × 3 = 9 dots in the grid.

questions.question_text: Which insect has spots arranged in a pattern on its back?
questions.explanation_correct: Ladybirds have distinctive black spots arranged on their red or orange wing covers — a recognizable pattern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ladybirds are known for their spotted pattern on their backs.

questions.question_text: Indian textiles like Bandhani (tie-dye) create patterns by tying and dyeing fabric.
questions.explanation_correct: Bandhani is a traditional Indian tie-dye technique where fabric is tied at many points before dyeing, creating repeating dot-like patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bandhani creates beautiful repeating patterns through tying and dyeing — a centuries-old Indian craft.

questions.question_text: Arun arranges marigold flowers for a garland: 2 orange, 1 yellow, 2 orange, 1 yellow. He needs a garland of 24 flowers. How many yellow flowers does he need?
questions.explanation_correct: Core = 2 orange + 1 yellow = 3 flowers. 24 ÷ 3 = 8 complete cores. Yellow = 8 × 1 = 8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 24 flowers ÷ 3 per core = 8 cores. Each core has 1 yellow. Total yellow = 8.

questions.question_text: The pattern of day and night is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Day and night alternate in a regular, repeating cycle — a natural repeating pattern caused by the Earth's rotation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Day-night is a natural repeating pattern (cycle) due to Earth's rotation.

questions.question_text: Which statement about Indian art patterns is TRUE?

options.text: Mehndi designs have no repeating elements
Indian art uses both geometric and floral patterns

questions.explanation_correct: Indian art extensively uses both geometric patterns (in tiles, jali work) and floral patterns (in mehndi, fabric design, architecture).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Indian art features both geometric and floral patterns across many art forms.

questions.question_text: A border design repeats its core every 4 cm. To fill a 28 cm border, the core repeats ___ times.
questions.explanation_correct: 28 ÷ 4 = 7 repetitions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 28 cm ÷ 4 cm per core = 7 complete repetitions.

questions.question_text: The seasons — summer, rainy, autumn, winter, spring — form a:
questions.explanation_correct: Seasons repeat every year in the same order — this is a repeating cycle, a natural pattern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seasons repeat cyclically every year — a natural repeating pattern.

questions.question_text: Sita makes a floor pattern using square tiles of 2 colours. She puts 4 blue tiles in a square, then surrounds them with white tiles. The first layer of white tiles needs:
questions.explanation_correct: A 2×2 blue centre. Surrounding it makes a 4×4 square. Border tiles = 4×4 - 2×2 = 16 - 4 = 12 white tiles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4×4 outer square - 2×2 inner = 16 - 4 = 12 white tiles.

questions.question_text: The paisley motif, commonly used in Indian textiles, originated in India.
questions.explanation_correct: The paisley (or 'boteh') design originated in Persia/India and is widely used in Indian shawls (especially Kashmiri), sarees, and textiles. The name 'paisley' comes from the Scottish town that copied the design.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The paisley motif has Indian/Persian origins and is a hallmark of Indian textile patterns.

questions.question_text: Vikram describes his pattern: 'I start with 1 circle and add 2 more circles in each step.' How many circles are in the 8th step?
questions.explanation_correct: Step 1: 1, Step 2: 3, Step 3: 5, Step 4: 7, Step 5: 9, Step 6: 11, Step 7: 13, Step 8: 15. Rule: 1 + (n-1)×2 = 2n-1. For n=8: 2(8)-1 = 15.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pattern: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15. The 8th step has 15 circles.
